What do I need to care for my boots?
>Old cotton t shirt (one for cleaning, another for applying conditioners)
>Horsehair brush ($10-15)
>Wooden shoe trees ($10-15)

>Heavy conditioner (if you live in terrible snow/rain areas) Sno seal/Obernauf LP
>Don't forget that boots need time to dry properly, rotate them and don't wear them daily for too long

How do I deal with x stain?
>mud: allow it to dry then brush off
>salt: water and cloth as soon as possible
>saturated wet: allow the boot to dry for a full day, stuff with newspaper
>scuffs and scratches: buff vigorously with horsehair brush

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17456900
First of all, you have curly hair. Secondly, only using shampoo will keep stripping all of the hydrating oils, which is what is making it so frizzy.

Use shampoo and then conditioner, only wash your hair every second night, and use a conditioning mask for 10-30min once a week. Don't rush your hair once it's dry - just run your fingers through while the conditioner is in it to separate tangles. You'll get some nice, smooth waves and curls.
You can use a leave-in oil product too if you want to go the extra mile. I out maybe a tablespoon of oil in my hair while it's soaking wet out of the shower, then leave to air dry (but it's much longer than yours, you'll figure out the perfect amount.)

Might want to try coal tar + salicylic acid shampoo. Be warned though it can strip whatever natural oil on your scalp and hair. Just use it on your scalp and condition your hair if shit dries them out.
>scab like flake
>red skin
Might want to just go to dermatologist, seems like scalp psoriasis. I managed to control mine by sparingly wash my hair (every 2-3 days) with water only and condition them with argan oil on my hair every 4-5 days. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm going to give a few first impressions of some samples I bought last week, I still need to try them more , but I dont think my opinion will change much after wearing them more:

>Baccarat rouge 540

Starts overtly sweet and synthetic, but once it dries down the sweetness fades away a bit and I start feeling it metallic and medicinal. I smell a lot of iodine and blood. I can get the cotton candy that everyone talks about if I really think about it when I smell it, but for me it's just blood, iodine and bandages. And for some reason, I might be a fucking perv, but I love it and I might consider buying it.

8.5

-Secretions magnifiques

Interesting meme fragrance, I bought the sample just out of curiosity and to me it smells like milk and a dog after a rain. A female friend that tried it with me liked it and she said it was really fresh and fruity to her and that she thought she could wear it no problem. A party experience fragrance more than anything.

>jubilation XXV
Smells like incense and raisins. I had a lot do expectations but it's a boring , simple , old smelling fragrance on my nose, and the performance is not that great. For me it's a worse interlude.

5.5/10

>Interlude 53

Sweeter interlude with similar performance. It loses a bit of its appeal with that sweetness but it's 90% the same fragrance. Good but redundant

8/10

>Aventus

The pineapple is rich and crisp on the opening and the fruit smells so nice that is almost gourmandish. On the drydown all the fruits go less sweet and the smoke comes in.

It's nice but it lasts less than one hour and a half on my skin and projects almost zero. Club de nuit intense limited edition is cheaper, and arguably better. The opening is worse, way worse, but the drydown while still different from the drydown of aventus is closer to that opening.

6.5/10 , the opening is one of the best I tried, the rest is dissappointing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17464803
>Xerjoff naxos

Incredibly rough opening that dries down into a really sweet dense inoffensive tobacco -honey-vanille blend. It's delicious but i wish it wasn't that sweet on the dry down, it can get a bit boring. Great performance

7.5/10

>Reflection man

One of the best white floral fragrances I've ever tried. The opening is heavenly and the dry down smells like the purest freshest jasmine you could ever smell early morning during spring. Not a fan of the peppery aspect of it, but it's really subtle, so it doesn't bother me much. Will probably get a bottle once the weather starts getting warmer.

9.5/10

>L'air du desert moroccain

I love the heart of the desert and I think this one is even better. The white florals are more present(I'm a sucked for neroli and jasmine) and the woodiness of it it's more creamy without getting sweet. On my nose it's like a room of an humid old house filled with white flowers, books and expensive wood furniture. Like waking up as a kid in your grandma's house. It's beautiful but it's not really versatile.
Just for special occasions.

9.5/10

>Molecule 01

Smells like burnt sunflower seeds and cardboard. The smell comes and goes (I guess your nose gets blind quickly ) and it lasts a lot but the scent is subtle and frankly, I don't see the point of wearing this.

5/10 because it smells nice, but it's almost not a fragrance. I haven't tried layering it yet.

>Bois imperial

Beautiful creamy woodiness on the opening that dissappears once it dries down and all you get after that is vetiver. Dissappointed because I expected something else, but it's not bad and it performs well. I smell some hints of mint, but it might be my nose.

7/10

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17465796
For me it's as close to a perfect fragrance as it gets. It opens very similar to Layton but a bit smoother and stays liek this for a couple of minutes. Then it starts to significantly diverge. The next 2-3 hours are heavily dominated by harsh and dry woods, ouds and some animalic notes (civet supposedly). You can also pick up some rose and very faint coffee. As it dries down it starts moving closer to the original Layton with the sweeter vanilla note becoing more prominent and you can tell it's the same DNA but, as there's no apple, thankfully it never transforms into apple pie scent. Ngl - especially in the mid part - it can a bit like vinegar pringles - you wouldn't say you like it but still keep coming back for more

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: kinda new to this. is performance really affected much by weather, or is it a meme?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17466266
Winter frags can turn out to be a bit suffocating in the heat summer

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17466266
To some degree, yes. Cold weather will cool your skin and cause your fragrance to not emit as much until you warm back up. Getting soaked enough from rain will dampen (figuratively and literally) your scent as it washes away. Strong, continuous wind will aerate the vapours that come off you.

Ideal conditions weather-wise are any hotter temperatures that make you feel comfortably warm - enough to help your fragrance evaporate and project more, but not so much that you're radiating. Early summer when you're in low 20s/mid to high 70s will be ideal.

With that said, seasonal frags are not a meme. Wearing heavy frags in summer daytime will be too intense and heavy; think drinking a rich hot chocolate on a summer's day.

Also the insulting lack of actual clothing stores in Finland. Go to any mall and the selection is insulting, it's the conception of what a gypsy or 30yr old arabs finds fashionable and "in"

These being mentioned, I think the soulless bauhaus-inspired architecture is a part of it too. Imagine you walked around more Parisian or classical Italian interiors (and exteriors), you would feel subconciously more aligned to dress accordingly in a sophisticated aesthetic manner. Instead everything in Nordic countries screams 21st century HR, marketing-friendly and keyboard tapping office-culture, so we're aeshtetically doomed.

It doesn't demoralize me tho, gives me more of a snowflake/exception from the norm-attitude the more i delve into dressing as far away from the Nordic soullesness as possible

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17455402
>>17455864
Yeah, it's a bad faith argument. When you say "milsurp" and ask if it can mix with TIP, you're obviously not asking if trench coats and khaki pants and desert boots are TIP, because they obviously are. You're asking if you can wear flecktarn and spetsnaz boots with a TIP fit and not look ridiculous, and the answer is generally "no." If you're going for the TIP aesthetic but like milsurp, that's fine, but save it for an appropriate situation like going hunting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17455373
I'd say I take a middle ground on this issue. Clothes that would be worn in combat 1970s-onward would clash, because combat gear from then on has been so drastically different from normal clothing. Earlier than that could possibly work, depending on the item. There are a lot of WWII items that can work with TIP clothes while still having more of an obviously military appearance than older heritage items like trench coats. Pic rel is a menswear blogger I like wearing a vintage Marine Corps service jacket with a TIP resort outfit.

All this philosophical stuff is really boring and, judging by his reply, none of your assumptions were actually correct anyways so its all irrelevant.

The problem with your whole line of thinking is that, at this point, the line of menswear has been completely severed for most guys in America. In the past, people would experiment with the kind of clothing their fathers wore, innovating within what society considered acceptable dress. Now many guys' fathers just wear t-shirts and jeans, and societal standards for everything have eroded into nothing. In that context, many young guys are going to start from scratch, without that kind of lovely effortless menswear wardrobe mindset you describe. So preaching that they should just have that instead of trying to look into particular styles for inspiration is pointless concern trolling. And again, really boring.

This >>17434391 is the advice you need. Just keep in mind what type of fit you're looking for. If you're considering getting one of their slim or slim tapered fits, be honest about whether this could be a little too tight. I've owned a pair of their slim tapered jeans and wore them for a few months only to find out that I absolutely hate the fit and prefer their straight tapered fit infinitely more since it gives me workable crotch mobility and doesn't have the feminine appearance of having the thighs too tight and the calve region being loose. If you order a pair only to find out you should have gone just one size up in waist, Iron Heart's customer service is top notch. If you're american, you could order a pair from Self Edge, Iron Shop Provisions, or Division Road and not have to deal with the longer shipping times from shipping overseas to Iron Heart's HQ in the UK.

Patagonia uses mostly recycled polyester.

This is a strawman, let me explain what I meant:
Most dyes used by cheap brands are bad for the environment because they are dumped irresponsibly and just made from impactful chemicals in general, and the washing process in production is also impactful, and all of the other treatments. They do it for as inane things as making the cloth softer or less prone to wrinkling, for basically every single piece of clothing you can find absolutely anywhere.

And to address the "poor people" comment, who do you think is dumping clothes by the side of the road or just buying loads of garbage in general? Is it people who buy clothing worth keeping (even a conscientious poor person will, but there are few of these in the West now with immigration and waves of dumbing the poor down), or is it poor people who buy garbage because it's cheap?

It adds up, by the way. It's very well known that it does. Your comment is idiotic for not being based on what happens in reality as opposed to what you'd suppose happens based on a couple qualities of the fibers and the processes.

Not to mention that one thing having a supposed lesser impact than another thing doesn't exempt it from doing any better.

>>17463487
As a fellow manlet I recommend going to a tailor, and trying out some different cuts. Generally speaking fit guys should go for slimmer pieces to accentuate their build. For example, a muscular guy with wide shoulders is going to look ridiculous in a sport coat with heavily padded shoulders. Also, high waisted trousers will make your legs appear longer, and wearing boots with one to two inch inserts in them will give you a good boost if you can bear them. All in all just go get your shit tailored (yes, even the casual stuff). I would avoid hats or trying to style your hair in a "tall" fashion as they both look goofy. You should, however, wear accessories that are in proportion with your size. You don't want chunky necklaces, bracelets, watches, etc.

Lastly, being a turbo manlet pretty much means you have to figure shit out on your own. No one can help you, and no one will feel sorry for you except for maybe other manlets. As you can see from the responses in this thread even the most "based" people in the dark corners of the internet will still respond like complete normies when it comes to the issue of height. Which is to say with vitriol, ridicule, anecdotal tales about how they know one short guy who fucks a lot, trite platitudes, muh Danny Devito and Kevin Hart, and just dogshit advice in general. They're not manlets so they dont' know any better, but they might as well be telling me 6 trillion jews died in the holocaust and niggers have 150IQ because that's how fucking retarded their advice is.

I want to keep this watch until I die, even if I will only wear it once in a blue moon.
I guess I'll decide once I talk to the watchmaker. I'll let you guys know then.

posts.com:
>>17465685
I'm back from the watchmakers and the news are worse than expected.
For once, Lip was never distributed in my country so there's no supply of movements or spare parts, I'll have to contact an old school watchmaker in France and hope for the best.
Regarding the quartz movement, there's no guarantee that the date will exactly match the window. On top of that they'll have to change the hands. They can get something very similar but the watch would lose part of its iconic look, and don't like the idea.
I found a movement online that might be adapted to the watch, but it's 90€ and I have no guarantee it would perfectly match the case and date window, nor if it will be compatible with my watch's hands.
Add to that that we're still talking about a movement made in the 70's that who knows how much life still has in it, even if it's working properlu now, and once it breaks we're back to square one.
So I was almost set in switching the movement for a quartz but I'll have to think about it.
Thanks for reading my blog.

>>17466280
I generally don't rank watches by price OR brand but by the watch itself. Something a pre-consolidation Cartier Santos-Dumont may not be that expensive, comparatively speaking, but it's definitely more interesting than anything on that list.

Of the guys at your table:

The Rolex is worn by an attorney who needs to be able to communicate to normie clients that he's successful. (He doesn't actually care about watches, but he likes to use the chrono to time his steaks when he's grilling.)

The Aquanaut is one of the lawyer's clients. Everyone at the table knows he's rich, but he' actually a LOT richer than anyone at the table knows.

The VC is worn by the Aquanaut wearer's friend, who knows he's not as rich as Aquanaut, but wants to appear as rich anyway.

The AP is worn by the attorney's friend (also an attorney) who's just gotten into watches recently and discovered Gerald Genta.

The Tudor is worn by the attorney's nephew. He just graduated from university and hasn't yet decided what he wants to do with his life. He'll probably spend a couple years travelling the globe before going to law school and working for his uncle.

The Snowflake is worn by one of the IT guys at the Aquanaut's company. He wasn't actually invited to dinner. He was sitting at the bar and he noticed his boss at a table, so he walked over to say hi. He failed to read the signals from everyone else and confused politeness with an invitation to sit down and join them.

In my book:

Oxfords are to be worn with a suit only.
Suede oxfords, loafers, NST derbies, balmoral boots are more 'business casual' but definitely not for jeans.
PTBs, plain toe derbies (at least 4 eyelets), chelseas, chukkas, dress boots, boat shoes can be jeans territory but not these sloppy baggy fits.
Sneakers, service boots, engineers and the like are strictly casual territory. Jeans, chinos, maybe cords and that's it.

I could be wrong

I had worse scars than you, but I was able to completely get rid of them when I was 21.

Tretinoin 0.05% every night and use a CeraVe or some other good but light moisturizer in the morning. Also wash your face with a Face Wash in the morning and before bed. Wait 15 minutes and allow your face to completely dry before applying Tretinoin at night and only apply with clean hands. Make sure to not get it near your eyes and lips though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17465342
This is bad advice, for multiple reasons.
First of all, you want a cosmetologist/skin beauty specialist - they focus in aesthetic treatments, i.e. what you want to tackle scarring.
Secondly, lasers are barbaric and expensive; there's easier, cheaper, significantly less painful ways of treating scars. Look into microneedling. Thirdly, retinoin will likely fuck you up to some degree because it's an acid that messes with your skin chemistry and will have varying effects for everyone. There's a reason it's not really prescribed anymore.

>https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
By June? Fill in numbers and see what results you get. If you're really just fat and are not physically active you'll need to cut a lot lower to look thin. You could lose 10kg by June with diet alone but then you'd need to lose even more. I suggest swimming or rowing for an hour a day while eating more protein at 500 cals under TDEE. Some say lifting is better and apparently having more muscle does raise TDEE but if you're just fat and sedentary, any consistent exercise will build some muscle. Swimming and rowing are great forms of cardio because they burn the most calories & both work almost every muscle in your body. Cardio also makes sex much better. Five months should be enough time assuming you're consistent with your intake and exercise.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17461172
Most of my stuff has been bought in person & as I’ve said it’s hard to find NA stuff in YG let alone made specifically for men, I assume that all mine is pretty old & from when gold was cheaper. As far as artists there’s hundreds of very collectible, talented artists just gotta do some research. Normally older stuff especially “old Indian pawn” is most desirable, all that means is it was made by Indians for Indians & not to sell to whites or tourists. Stuff from the 50s-80s is also very desirable as it has turquoise from mines that are no longer active. I’m from the east coast but my grandparents moved out west & spent their retirement buying southwestern/western/NA art (Remington bronzes, Pueblo pottery, paintings, ect) so I learned a lot about it from him. Look for shops in wealthy western towns in Utah, Colorado, Montana, Wyoming, arizona, & so forth. There’s unending research to be done on the topic tho, I’ll link u cuff I really like that’s two tone & some other reputable dealers, you can search for gold products on there sites I’m sure but good stuff gold or silver won’t be cheap.

Never bought from any of these but have looked around, all have some nice stuff.
www.abbykentflythefineart.com

www.fineindianart.com

www.sedonaindianjewelry.com

www.shopgarlands.com

Below is some good resources.
www.horsekeeping.com/native-american-jewelry-artifacts.htm

Finally that cuff I was speaking about. they have a smaller one also but I think it’s a bit mass produced & over priced, my big cuff was less than that, it does look nice tho. tomtaylorbuckles.com/collections/bracelets-cuffs/products/carico-lake-turquoise-cuff

White-collar professional in my 20s

I have large, soft hands. Yet I hate wearing rings. Just don't like things getting in the way when I have to write, type, wash, moisturise, etc.

Locket with photos of loved ones in it could possibly be cool. Otherwise, a decent wrist watch with a versatile look is enough for most dudes. Twinks and prettyboys obv can get away with gaudy shit. If you have thick skin, hairy or rugged hands, the style of jewelry has to match, otherwise it looks awful.

Fair warning to anons, as an antique collector with his own wheelhouse, spend a lot of time learning to study fakes and replicas from all eras before starting any sort of purchase/collection. If you spot something you like IRL, come back and look at it later when you've had the time to research the item. Fakes of each piece can be fairly idiosyncratic. Be very careful and slow to start when switching tracks into a different field. That Bulgarian on esty is the perfect reason why.

Platinum and palladium are the best platinoid metals for jewelry, can't say much about ruthenium and iridium since they're very rarely used as far as I know

I'm aging well so far, but I sure as hell am trying to do my best to not leave it up to chance. I'm 26.

I do A313 retinol, sunscreen (if I actually go out), cleanser and moisturizer.

I eat once per day to stay lean and to have long periods of fasting. It's surprisingly easy to get used to this, and I love overeating, so anyone can do it. Lost about 15kgs now that I can confirm with scales in a few months. I'm poor so my diet is not perfect.

I don't smoke or drink. I used to drink beer more often, but I cut it out almost entirely. I like wine and live in a wine country, so I might drink a glass rarely.

I will start doing cardio, but I don't want to overdo it. I've heard HIIT is better for the body than traditional long distance running. NGL I was never good at this so I'd like to get in conditioning where I can run 30km at least once in my life.

I will start supplementing collagen, 25g per day when I can afford to buy it in bulk per kilo.
